abstract_summ: This study analyzed global COVID-19 epidemiological trends, examined impact of the pandemic on global health security, diplomacy, and social environment in China, and provided short- and long-term strategic policy recommendations for China's subsequent preparedness and responses.We summarized the effective intervention and prevention measures in the fields of public health response, clinical management, and research development in China, which may provide vital lessons for the global response.Malaysia has recorded the highest number of COVID-19 cases in Southeast Asia with more than 35% of new COVID-19 cases linked to the Sri Petaling gathering, a Moslem missionary movement attended by more than 19 000 people of different nationalities, in March 2020 in Kuala Lumpur.Community containment includes measures that range from increasing social distancing to community-wide quarantine.The impact of communicable diseases (infectious diseases) on human health is obvious.
title_summ: The Effectiveness of Targeted Quarantine for Minimising Impact of COVID-19Control Strategies to Curtail Transmission of COVID-19Effectiveness of the strategies implemented in SriLanka for controlling the COVID-19 outbreakPotential roles of social distancing in mitigating the spread of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in South KoreaWheat and chaffs in the interpretation of the current COVID19 outbreak in ItalyOnly strict quarantine measures can curb the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Italy, 2020Complex emergencies of COVID-19: management and experience in Zhuhai, ChinaCOVID-19 containment: China provides important lessons for global responseCommunity Responses during Early Phase of COVID-19 Epidemic, Hong KongThe Covid-19 pandemic in Denmark: Big lessons from a small countryCOVID-19 outbreak: current scenario of PakistanA Single Mass Gathering Resulted in Massive Transmission of COVID-19 Infections in Malaysia with Further International SpreadThe ongoing crises in China illustrate that the assessment of epidemics in isolation is no longer sufficientIsolation, quarantine, social distancing and community containment: pivotal role for old-style public health measures in the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreakSolidarity in response to COVID-19 outbreak in the Eastern Mediterranean Region.[COVID-19 Pandemic: global epidemiological trends and China's subsequent preparedness and responses].Global surge in measles and major international survey reinforce the need for greater awareness and uptake of all vaccinations.
title_abstract_phrases: In this review the authors discuss about the many wheat and chaffs of how this virus disease is addressed .Only strict quarantine measures can curb the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Italy, 2020Several Italian towns are under lockdown to contain the COVID-19 outbreak.This study analyzed global COVID-19 epidemiological trends, examined impact of the pandemic on global health security, diplomacy, and social environment in China, and provided short- and long-term strategic policy recommendations for China's subsequent preparedness and responses.A Single Mass Gathering Resulted in Massive Transmission of COVID-19 Infections in Malaysia with Further International SpreadMalaysia has recorded the highest number of COVID-19 cases in Southeast Asia with more than 35% of new COVID-19 cases linked to the Sri Petaling gathering, a Moslem missionary movement attended by more than 19 000 people of different nationalities, in March 2020 in Kuala Lumpur.On 12 March 2020, the outbreak of COVID-19 was characterized as a pandemic.[COVID-19 Pandemic: global epidemiological trends and China's subsequent preparedness and responses].The outbreak of COVID-19 has spread quickly across 114 countries/territories/areas in six continents worldwide and has been announced as a pandemic by WHO.Isolation, quarantine, social distancing and community containment: pivotal role for old-style public health measures in the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreakPublic health measures were decisive in controlling the SARS epidemic in 2003.
